facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1955 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 14th March, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 27 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1955. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 14th March, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 27 of 1952.

facts.text: The assessee is a non-resident company with head office in London and branches in India.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, respondent before us, is a number-resident companypany which has its head office in London and branches in India.

facts.text: The assessee sells and publishes books and magazines in various parts of the world.

anchor.surface_text: It sells and publishes books and magazines in various parts of the world. For the assessment year in question, it submitted a return of income

facts.text: Assessee submitted return using fixed percentage of marked price as cost of production for publications sold in India.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year in question, it submitted a return of income in which with regard to all publications sold in India, whether printed in India or elsewhere, a fixed percentage of what was known as the marked price was adopted as the companyt of production.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer accepted the method and assessed the assessee on Rs. 82,623.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer apparently accepted it and subject to certain minor modifications as respects some items of expenditure and an alleged bad debt with which we are number number companycerned, assessed the assessee on an income of Rs. 82,623.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner enhanced assessment to Rs. 1,11,616.

anchor.surface_text: The latter issued a numberice under s. 31 3  of the Act against the assessee, and after hearing the assessee, enhanced the assessment of the assessee companypanys business income to Rs. 1,11,616.

facts.text: Total turnover Rs. 16,01,973 for previous year ending 30th May, 1943, gross profit Rs. 4,09,360 (25.5%).

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner found It is numbericed that on total turnover of Rs. 16,01,973 for the previous year ending 30th May, 1943, the gross profit amounted to Rs. 4,09,360 working out to just about 25.5 per cent.

facts.text: World profit and loss: gross profit £231,070 on sales £628,000 (over 37%).

anchor.surface_text: In the case of World profit and loss account I find that the gross profit earned was pound 231,070 on total sales of pound 628,000 working out to over 37 per cent.

facts.text: AAC fixed income based on net world profit applied to Indian business.

anchor.surface_text: He fixed the income of the assessee companypany on the basis of the net world profit of the assessee on its world turnover, and applying that basis to its Indian business came to the companyclusion that the income of the assessee was Rs. 1, 1 1,616.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal remanded case to AAC, but later held no jurisdiction after Bombay HC decision in K.F. Vakeel v. CIT.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal remanded the case to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, but before the remand companyld be decided came the decision of the Bombay High Court in K. F. Vakeel v. The Commissioner of Income-tax  1 . The Tribunal then held that in view of that decision, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had numberjurisdiction

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax asked Tribunal to refer questions to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City, appellant before us, asked the Tribunal to submit certain questions of law to the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered first two questions in the negative by judgment dated March 4, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment and order dated March 4, 1953, the High Court answered the first two questions in the negative and held-rightly in our view-that the third question did number arise.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then asked for and obtained special leave to appeal from the said judgment and order of the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Assessment year 1944-45, year of account ended April 30, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1944-45 the respondent was assessed under the Act as a number-resident companypany. Its year of account ended on April 30, 1943.

facts.text: Head office invoices to Indian branches at 25% of marked price for sterling publications and 30% for currency publications.

anchor.surface_text: The Head Office and branches outside India invoice publications to the Indian branches number at companyt but at a valuation which is 25 of the marked price for sterling publications and 30 of the marked price for currency publications

facts.text: ITO assessed business income at Rs. 82,623 by order dated March 24, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: By his assessment order dated March 24, 1945, the Income tax Officer accepted the method of accounting employed by the respondent and its books of account for the Indian business.

facts.text: AAC enhanced to Rs. 1,11,616 by order dated November 10, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the respondent the Appellate Assistant Commissioner made an order dated November 10, 1948, calculating the Indian business profits of the respondent

facts.text: Tribunal allowed appeal by order dated October 16, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribuna accepted these companytentions of the respondent and by its order dated October 16, 1951, allowed the appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 16, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957 October 16. The judgment of S. K. Das and J. L. Kapur JJ. was delivered by S. K. Das J. Bhagwati J. delivered a separate judgment.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and answered questions in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must, therefore, be allowed the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay dated March 4, 1953, is set aside and the two questions referred to the said High Court are answered in favour of the Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: definition of Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Officer in ss. 2(3)

issues.text: Whether it is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to reject the assessee's method of accounting purporting to act under the proviso to s. 13 of the Act, when the Income-tax Officer has accepted the self-same method of accounting?

anchor.surface_text: The first question appears to us to have been somewhat widely framed and, in the terms in which it has been expressed, is not confined to the method of accounting referred to in s. 13 of the Act. The Income-tax Officer, even when he accepts the assessee's method of accounting, is not bound by the figure of profits shown in the accounts. If and when an appeal is taken by the assessee to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, the latter can re-examine the books of account to test the correctness of the assessment made. It is not disputed before us that accounts must be distinguished from the method of accounting. Section 13 and its proviso are concerned with the method of accounting. In the context of the statement of the case, however, the first question really means this: is it open to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, on an appeal preferred by the assessee, to reject for the first time the method of accounting, purporting to act under the proviso to s. 13 of the Act, on the ground that the income, profits and gains cannot be properly deduced therefrom, when the Income-tax Officer although he has not expressly said so must be taken to have accepted the self-same method of accounting ?

issues.text: Whether it is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to invoke the provisions of Rule 33 of the Indian Income-tax Rules for the purpose of computing the income of a non-resident, the Income-tax Officer not having done so?

anchor.surface_text: These questions were Whether it is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to reject the assessees books of account, which have been accepted by the Income. tax Officer Whether it is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to invoke the provisions of Rule 33 of the Indian Income-tax Rules for the purpose of computing the income of a non-resident, the Income-tax Officer not having done so ?

issues.text: Whether it is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to enhance an assessment in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by section 31(3)(a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, where as a result of definite information he is of opinion that the income of the assessee has been under-assessed?

anchor.surface_text: Whether it is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to enhance an assessment in exercise of the powers conferred upon him by section 31 3  a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, where as a result of definite information he is of opinion that the income of the assessee has been under-assessed?

issues.text: Whether the determination of the Income-tax Officer under the proviso to s. 13, in so far as such determination depends on his opinion, is final or not?

anchor.surface_text: Ancillary to the aforesaid two main contentions, there is a further divergence of opinion as to whether the determination of the Income-tax Officer under the proviso to s. 13, in so far as such determination depends on his opinion, is final or not.

issues.text: Whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can exercise the power under the proviso to s. 13 if the Income-tax Officer failed to apply his mind to it?
